cards.front:
Which of the following statements regarding the Salmonella bacterium is correct?

A. The Salmonella bacterium itself causes food poisoning.
B. Refrigeration of food will prevent salmonellosis.
C. The Salmonella bacterium produces toxins that cause food poisoning.
D. Symptoms of salmonellosis appear within 12 hours.
See Food Poisoning
cards.back: The Salmonella bacterium itself causes food poisoning.

cards.front:
Which of the following questions would be least pertinent during the initial questioning of a patient who ingested a substance?

A. How long ago was the substance taken?
B. Why was the substance ingested?
C. What type of substance was taken?
D. How much of the substance was taken?
See Identifying the Patient and the Poison

Your priority in caring for a patient with a surface contact poisoning is to:

A. avoid contaminating yourself.
B. obtain and maintain a patent airway.
C. decontaminate the patient’s skin.
D. move the patient to a safe area.
See How Poisons Enter the Body

A patient who presents with rapid breathing, nausea and vomiting, ringing in the ears, and hyperthermia should be suspected of ingesting a significant quantity of:

A. ibuprofen.
B. acetaminophen.
C. aspirin.
D. cocaine.
See Specific Poisons

If you are uncertain how to treat a patient who has been poisoned or exposed to a specific substance, you should:

A. try to find the container the substance was in.
B. administer naloxone via the intranasal route.
C. keep the patient supine and elevate his legs.
D. encourage the patient to drink milk or water.
See How Poisons Enter the Body
cards.back: try to find the container the substance was in.

cards.front:
A person who routinely misuses a substance and requires increasing amounts to achieve the same effect is experiencing:

A. dependence.
B. withdrawal.
C. addiction.
D. tolerance.
See Specific Poisons

After administering activated charcoal to a patient, it is most important to:

A. call medical control.
B. monitor the patient’s blood pressure.
C. document the intervention.
D. be alert for vomiting.
See Emergency Medical Care

The poison control center will provide you with the most information regarding the appropriate treatment for a patient with a drug overdose if the center:

A. knows why the patient overdosed on the drug.
B. is aware of the substance that is involved.
C. knows the location of the closest hospital.
D. is aware of the patient’s age and gender.
See How Poisons Enter the Body
cards.back: is aware of the substance that is involved.

cards.front:
The major side effect associated with administration of activated charcoal is:

A. black stools.
B. abdominal pain.
C. headache.
D. ringing in the ears.
See Emergency Medical Care

What type of poisoning will cause burns around the mouth in children?

A. Injected poison.
B. Plant poisoning.
C. Alkaline poison.
D. Inhaled poison.
See How Poisons Enter the Body

Common names for activated charcoal include all of the following, except:

A. InstaChar.
B. Fructose.
C. Actidose.
D. LiquiChar.
See Emergency Medical Care

Hypotension, hypoventilation, and pinpoint pupils would be expected following an overdose of:

A. crack cocaine.
B. oxycodone (Percocet).
C. ecstasy.
D. amphetamine sulfate (Benzedrine).
See Specific Poisons

Most poisonings occur via the __________ route.

A. injection
B. inhalation
C. absorption
D. ingestion
See How Poisons Enter the Body

Heroin is an example of a(n):

A. sympathomimetic.
B. hypnotic.
C. cholinergic.
D. opioid.
See Specific Poisons

An EMT’s primary responsibility to the patient who has been poisoned is to:

A. recognize that a poisoning occurred.
B. administer the appropriate antidote.
C. contact poison control immediately.
D. administer 25 g of activated charcoal.
See Identifying the Patient and the Poison

Signs and symptoms of a sympathomimetic drug overdose include:

A. tachycardia.
B. hypotension.
C. slurred speech.
D. hypothermia.
See Specific Poisons

Activated charcoal may be indicated for a patient who ingested:

A. methanol.
B. ethanol.
C. aspirin.
D. iron.
See Emergency Medical Care

A hypnotic drug is one that:

A. increases the senses.
B. induces sleep.
C. increases the pulse.
D. prevents amnesia.
See Specific Poisons

Airborne substances should be diluted with:

A. an alkaline antidote.
B. activated charcoal.
C. oxygen.
D. syrup of ipecac.
See Patient Assessment

Substance abuse is most accurately defined as:

A. knowingly selling illicit drugs to buy more drugs.
B. misusing a substance to produce a desired effect.
C. unwillingly and unknowingly consuming drugs or alcohol.
D. willfully using a therapeutic drug to treat a medical illness.
See Identifying the Patient and the Poison
cards.back: misusing a substance to produce a desired effect.
